abstract.text: Tells the delegate that the data for continuing an activity is available.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The shared app object that controls and coordinates your app.
The activity object containing the data associated with the task the user was performing. Use the data to continue the user’s activity in your iOS app.

A block to execute if your app creates objects to perform the task the user was performing. Calling this block is optional and you can copy this block and call it at a later time. When calling a saved copy of the block, you must call it from the app’s main thread. This block has no return value and takes the following parameter:
An array of objects that conform to
that represent the objects you created or fetched in order to perform the operation. The system calls the
method of each object in the array to give it a chance to perform the operation.
restorableObjects
to indicate that your app handled the activity or
to let iOS know that your app didn’t handle the activity.
The app calls this method when it receives data associated with a user activity, for example, when the user transfers an activity from a different device using Handoff.
Implement this method to update your iOS app so that the user can continue the activity from where they left off. If you don’t implement this method or if your implementation returns
, iOS tries to create a document for your app to open using a URL.
Calling the block in the
is optional and only needed when specific objects are capable of continuing the activity.
This method isn’t called if either
or
returns
This method is called whenever your app is launched to handle a SiriKit intent. Update your app’s user interface based on the
parameter. Your app should seamlessly continue the interaction that began in Siri.
By default, the intent provides an
object whose
property contains both the originating intent and your response. You can add additional, app-specific information by creating a new
object in your intent’s
or
method and adding your data to the activity’s
dictionary.
When continuing activities from SiriKit:
Look for the intent specified in the
property. Resume handling this intent in your app.
Avoid accidentally repeating actions (such as making double payments). For example, check the
doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/sirikit/ininteraction
object’s
doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/sirikit/ininteraction/1638817-intentresponse
property to see if the action has already been completed.
Intents may launch your app under the following circumstances:
Some intents always launch the app after the intent is successfully handled (for example, intents with a
response code).
Your intent’s
and
methods launch the app when you resolve the intent with a
(or similar) response code.
The user can always decide to launch the app at any point in a Siri transaction.

abstract.text: A representation of the state of your app at a moment in time.
A dictionary containing app-specific state information needed to continue an activity on another device.
The SiriKit interaction object to use when configuring your app.
A false value.
A true value.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
The centralized point of control and coordination for apps running in iOS.
A set of methods to manage shared behaviors for your app.
Tells the delegate that the data for continuing an activity is available.
Tells the delegate that the activity couldn’t be continued.
Tells the delegate that the launch process is almost done and the app is almost ready to run.
Tells the delegate that the activity was updated.
Tells the delegate that the user selected a Home screen quick action for your app, except when you’ve intercepted the interaction in a launch method.
Tells the delegate if your app takes responsibility for notifying users when a continuation activity takes longer than expected.
Tells the delegate that the launch process has begun but that state restoration hasn’t occured.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
Restores the state necessary to continue the specified user activity.
Type to represent a Boolean value.
A representation of the state of your app at a moment in time.
A value type whose instances are either `true` or `false`.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
